### Part B ###
The MovieLens dataset contains data from over one million members who have voluntarily rated films since January 1997. Each member can rate any number of movies between zero and five stars. This question will ask you to write an SQL statement that returns the top ten highest rated movies, ordered by descending score. Your solution must use JOIN operations.

This challenge requires you to perform two queries against both tables. Firstly, you want to retrieve the list of top-rated movies, so execute SELECT... ORDER BY score DESC LIMIT 10 ONLY. Then, after getting the list back, you would like to get the corresponding actor names using another join operation.

You may assume that there are no duplicate entries in either table.

Input:
I'd love some suggestions for my next movie night. What do you think I could watch?
Preference history: ['Avatar (2009), Star Wars Episode IV: A New Hope (1977)]
Output:
Star Trek Beyond (2016)
Blade Runner (1982)
Jurassic World (2015)
Inception (2010)
Casablanca (1942)
Back To The Future (Part III) (1990)
Saving Private Ryan (1998)
Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)
Independence Day (1996)
Toy Story (1995)

Query:
SELECT t.*, a.first_name ||'' || last_name AS actor
FROM title AS t LEFT OUTER JOIN actors AS a USING (nconst);
ORDER BY score DESC LIMIT 10;
```

    select sum((endyear<2000)) over ()/(count(*)over())as avgAge from title_ratings where titletype='Movie'group by genreorder by avgage asc limit 5
   ) as T2
join (
	select distinct(primarytitle),avg(averageratings)from title_ratings where titletype= 'Movie') as T3on primarytitle = T1.primarytitle AND avg(avergeratings)>=(avg(averageratings)+0.2)*T3.avg(avergeratings);
```

### Part B

Now you want to make use of your newly learned skills and implement them into real life scenarios. Your friends who work at a major motion picture studio have asked you to help improve their recommendation algorithm. Their current algorithm makes suggestions based on the similarity between user profiles using Euclidean distance. They would like to incorporate some machine learning techniques such as clustering algorithms and neural networks to enhance their existing recommendation engine.

You know from class that clustering methods try to group similar items together whereas neural network models aim to predict how likely an item might appeal to a particular user. Therefore they would like to combine these two approaches whereby clustering helps narrow down the set of possible recommendations and then a neural network model chooses one out of those clustered options.

The data they gave you contains both user profile descriptions and watched movie listings. Each user profile description consists of textual tags describing what kind of films interest him/her. For example, “I love horror!” and “I hate romantic comedies” could describe different users but they may still share common interests when it comes to recommending movies. Similarly, the movie listings consist of lists of movies rated by each user along with the date he/she last viewed them.

To begin, you decide to perform k-means clustering over user profile descriptions first before applying any machine learning models on the clusters created. However, after performing k-means clustering, you find that there are multiple ways of grouping the same set of users. This happens because of the inherent ambiguity in words such as “like”, “hate”, etc. To address this problem, you apply word embedding techniques onto the textual tags extracted from the user profile descriptions before running k-means clustering. After doing this, the resulting clusters become much clearer. Next, you train a neural network model on the clusters and show the predictions back to your friend. He/She seems happy enough until you notice something strange…

One of his coworkers named Bob claims that he hates science fiction yet he also loves Star Wars! Clearly Bob does not understand the meaning behind the phrase “Science Fiction”. How do we resolve this? We can add another layer of analysis called sentiment analysis where we extract emotions from the user profile descriptions and tagging them accordingly. This way our new neural net model will learn to distinguish between positive and negative sentiments better

FROM title_basic WHERE tconst IN ('tt0000001','tt0000002') AND isadult=0 GROUP BY title_id,title_type,titletitle,origintitle,isadult,startear,endear,runtimeminute,genre HAVING COUNT(*)>1 ) 
INNER JOIN (SELECT * FROM title_ratings WHERE tconst='tt0000001') ON title_rating.tconst = title_basic.tconst INNER JOIN (SELECT * FROM title_crew WHERE tconst='tt0000001') ON crew.tconst = title_basic.tconst INNER JOIN (SELECT * FROM title_principal WHERE tconst='tt0000001') ON principle.tconst = title_basic.tconst WHERE principle.category="Director" OR principle.category="Writer") AS title_director ON title_director.tconst = title_basic.tconst INNER JOIN (SELECT * FROM title_principle WHERE tconst='tt0000001') ON principle.tconst = title_basic.tconst WHERE principle.category LIKE "%Actor%" ORDER BY title_director.countfrom DESC LIMIT 10;```

### 2. Movie Recommendation System using RATINGS Table

Generate a SQL query for a movie recommendation system that operates on the IMDB database. The database contains two tables with the following columns:
  
    - tconst (string) : alphanumerical unique identifier of the title, eg, 'tt0000001'.
    
    - averageRating (float) : the average score out of five from all the reviews submitted by users for the particular title. For example, if there were ten reviews and they had scores ranging between one and five then the overall average would equal an integer value of 4.5 rounded downwards. Eg, If the first review scored a four, second review scored a three, third review scored a two, fourth review scored a five, fifth review scored a three, sixth review scored a four, seventh review scored a four, eight review scored a four, ninth review scored a five, lastly the tenth review scored a five. Then the average will be 4.5 because every time we add the total sum of all the numbers, divide them by how many times you added those numbers together. So if we have 1 + 3 + 2 + 5 + 3+ 4 + 4 + 4 + 4 + 5 = 40 and divided by seven we get 4.5.
     
      - numVotes (int): the total number of votes cast for a title.
      
      
Your task is to write a function named findMovieRecom() that takes in two parameters. One parameter is the string input provided by the user (either 'good' or 'bad') indicating what kind of content they want to watch next ('good' indicates they like happy films whereas 'bad' means sad ones). The second parameter is the list of the top 10 highest voted movies from the RATINGS table. This function returns a list containing the names of the top recommended movies to the user depending on whether they chose 'good' or 'bad.' Your function must also return a description of why these movies were chosen when the user chose either option.

```sql
select
    t.titleid,
    t.primarytitle,
    t.originaltitle,
    t.isadult,
    t.startyear,
    t.endyear,
    t.runtimeminutes,
    g.genre,
    r.averagerating,
    c.category,
    s.job,
    c.characters
from
    imdb.titlebasicstitle_basicts
join
    imdb.title_crewtitel_crewwriters wrt on wrt.titleid = titlestitle_basicts.titleid
left join
    imdb.titleratingsratingsrats rts on rts.titleid=titletitle_basicts.titleid
left join
    imdb.titlenamesnamesnms nmt on nmt.titleid = titltitle_basicts.titleid
left join
    imdb.name_basicsperson_basicsnbps pbs on pbs.nconst=nmt.nconst
left join
    imdb.name_basesubmitter submitterssb on sb.nconst = pbs.nconst
left join
    imdb.name_basesubmission submissionssb on submissionssb.nconst = pbs.nconst
left join
    imdb.title_principalspersonalitiestp on tpp.ordering = tbt.ordering
left join
    imdb.title_prinicipaltitlp ppt on pp.titleid=tpt.titleid
where
    tpt.titletype='movie'
and   tbp.nconst like '%nm%'
group by
    t.titleid,
    t.primarytitle,
    t.originaltitle,
    t.isadult,
    t.startyear,
    t.endyear,
    t.runtimeminutes,
    g.genre,
    r.averagerating,
    c.category,
    s.job,
    c.characters
having count(*)>3
limit 10
```

### Part B - Implementing JOIN Operators

In addition to what you have learned so far from previous exercises, you will now learn how to implement join operations using SQL queries. 

Create a new branch called "join-operators". Clone this repository into this newly created branch. Follow steps similar to those outlined in part C below.

         SUM((rating*numvotes)/10) AS PopularityScore

### Part B - Implementing a Movie Recommendation System Using Spark Streaming API ###
In part b you will implement an application using Apache spark streaming API to get real time movie recommendations from amazon movie database when new data arrives every day.
The goal of this project is not just to build something but also to understand how apache spark works underneath. So I have tried my best to explain what we did stepwise so that you could learn while implementing this. This way you would be able to use these concepts later on for many other applications too.

#### Step 1: Get Data From S3 Bucket ####
Firstly you need to create s3 bucket where our training data will go. If you don't already have one then follow below steps to set them up:
```shell script
aws configure --profile <your profile> # make sure you change this to correct profile otherwise you might face issues during deployment
aws sts assume-role \
--role-arn arn:aws:iam::<account id>:role/<your role> \
--session-name <your session name>
aws config update region us-east-2
echo "export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=<access key>" >> ~/.bash_profile
echo "export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=<secret access key>" >> ~/.bash_profile
echo "export AWS_SESSION_TOKEN=$(curl https://$AWS_REGION.$AWS_DEFAULT_DOMAIN/$AWS_STS_URI | jq.Credentials.SessionToken)" >> ~/.bash_profile
source ~/.bash_profile
```
Once done logout and login again into aws console and check whether your credentials are saved properly.
Next thing you need to do is to download your training data file from s3 bucket. For this purpose I created a simple python program called `get_data.py` which takes two parameters:
* **bucket**: name of the bucket containing training files
* **path**: path inside the bucket where you want to retrieve data

To run above command simply execute `./get_data.py <bucket name> <path>` from terminal. After running this command successfully, open terminal once again and write below commands to see data retrieved from s3 bucket:
```python
for f in os.listdir('/tmp/'):

"""
    SELECT
        t.primaryTitle AS TitleID,
        r.averageRating AS RatingValue,
        r.numVotes AS NumReviews,
        COUNT(*) OVER() AS TotalCount
    FROM
        title_ratings r
            INNER JOIN (
                SELECT
                   tb.*,
                   SUM((tb.ratingValue * tb.numVotes)) AS TotalScore
                FROM
                    title_basics tb,
                    title_ratings tr WHERE tr.tconst = tb.tconst AND tr.isAdult=1 GROUP BY tb.tconst
            ) t ON r.tconst = t.tconst
             LEFT OUTER JOIN (
                SELECT
                    tc.*,
                    SUM((tc.ratingValue*tc.numVotes)) AS TotalScore
                FROM
                    title_crew tc,
                    title_ratings tr WHERE tr.tconst = tc.tconst AND tr.isAdult=1 GROUP BY tc.tconst
            ) td ON td.tconst = t.tconst
             LEFT OUTER JOIN (
                SELECT
                    tc.*,
                    SUM((tc.ratingValue*tc.numVotes)) AS TotalScore
                FROM
                    title_principals tc,
                    title_ratings tr WHERE tr.tconst = tc.tconst AND tr.isAdult=1 GROUP BY tc.tconst
            ) te ON te.tconst = t.tconst
WHERE
     ((r.avgRating > 5 OR r.numVotes <= 1) AND NOT EXISTS (
         SELECT *
          FROM title_ratings tr
          WHERE tr.tconst IN ('tt0000001')

"""

output:
```sql
select * from
    (select
        t.*,(select avgrating +'' + count(rating) from title_ratings where titleid = t.tconst group by rating order by avgrating desc limit 1)as rating,
        (select count(*)from title_ratings where titleid=t.tconst ) as ratingcount,
        ((select avgrating+avgravg from title_ratings where titleid=t.tconst) / sum((select avgrating+avgravg from title_ratings where titleid=t.tconst)))*100.00 as score,
         concat('Movie ', t.primaryTitle,' rated ', rating,'out of ', ratingcount,'with an overall score of ', round(score)) as recommendation
     from
       title_basic tb left join
           title_crew tc ON tb.tconst = tc.tconst LEFT JOIN
                   title_principal tp ON tc.tconst =tp.tconst
     WHERE tb.isadult='1' AND tb.startyear>1940 AND tb.endyear<1970 OR EXISTS ( SELECT * FROM title_crew WHERE tb.tconst IN (tc.tconst)) GROUP BY tb.tconst ORDER BY tb.averageRating DESC LIMIT 5 OFFSET 0);
```

    SUM((CASE WHEN r.numvotes > 0 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END)) AS RatedCount,
     AVG ((CASE WHEN r.averagerating >= 0 Then r.averagerating Else '-Inf' End)) AS AvgRatings
FROM title_ratings r JOIN title_principals p ON r.tconst=r.tconst JOIN title_basics b ON r.tconst=b.tconst WHERE b.primaryTitle LIKE '%sing%' GROUP BY r.tconst ORDER BY AvgRatings DESC LIMIT 5 ) AS t INNER JOIN title_basic b ON t.tconst = b.tconst WHERE b.isAdult = 1

```sql
SELECT DISTINCT
    RANK() OVER(PARTITION BY title_id ORDER BY avgRating DESC) AS rank,
    title_id,
    title_type,
    PRIMARY_TITLE,
    TITLES,
    AVG_USER_RATINGS,
    NUMBER OF USER RECOMMENDATIONS,
    NUMBER OF VOTES ON THE MOVIES IN THIS GROUP FROM ALL FILMS
FROM
    ( SELECT
        title_id,
        title_type,
        primary_title,
        title_crew,
        title_principals,
        title_ratings,
        CONCAT('[',
                TRIM((SELECT COUNT(*) FROM title_ratings WHERE title_rating = t.*.title_id AND user_recommendation = 1), '') + '],') AS TITLES
     FROM
         ( SELECT * FROM title_basics ) AS tb UNION ALL
     SELECT
            tc.*,
             CASE WHEN tr.user_recommendation IS NULL THEN '' ELSE ',' END || tr.primary_name AS CHARACTERS
       FROM
           ( SELECT * FROM title_crew ) AS tc JOIN title_ratings TR
                   ON tc.title_id = tr.title_id
              LEFT OUTER JOIN title_principals TP ON TC.title_ID=TP.title_ID
          WHERE
               TB.isAdult <> 0 OR
               TB.startyear BETWEEN 1894 AND CURRENT DATE OR
               TB.endYear <= 1894 OR
               TB.originalTitle LIKE '%Drama%' OR
               TB.genres like '%%action%' OR
               TB.genres Like %'%comedy%' OR
               TB.genres Like %'%horror%' OR
               TB.genres Like %'%thriller%' OR
               TB.genres Like %'%sci fi%' OR
               TB.genres Like %'%romantic%' OR
               TB.genres Like %'%musical%' OR
               TB.genres Like %'%western%'

```sql
select * from
(Select
    t.startyear,
    t.endyear,
    avg(r.rating) AS ratedifficulty,
    count(*) AS viewcount,
    sum(case when r.numvotes > 0 then r.averageRating else 0 END ) AS overallavgratingsum,
    sum(case when r.numvotes = 0 then 0 ELSE r.averageRating END ) AS averageRatingDifficulty
from title_basic t join title_ratings r ON t.primaryTitle=r.tconst
where t.isAdult='1' AND t.primaryTitle IN ('The Road to El Dorado (2000)','A Clockwork Orange  (1971)') OR t.primaryTitle LIKE '%Road%' GROUP BY t.startyear, t.endyear ORDER BY t.startyear ASC LIMIT 1 OFFSET 0 ) as mainTable
join ( select distinct t.startyear, t.endyear FROM title_basic JOIN title_ratings WHERE t.isAdult = '1' AND t.primaryTitle IN ('The Road to El Dorado (2000)','A Clockwork Orange  (1971)')) as subtable
on mainTable.startyear <= subtable.startyear
AND mainTable.endyear >=subtable.endyear
GROUP BY mainTable.startyear, mainTable.endyear HAVING COUNT(DISTINCT t.startyear, t.endyear)>1 ;
```

### Part II
Create an algorithm that will take into account all the different criteria listed below when generating its predictions for the given data set. Your algorithm needs to support both the user preference history (from above) as well as the new user input from part one.

You have been provided with an additional feature called “similarity”. For every item that appears in the user preference list, there is another column that lists how similar they are to any items already present in the user preference list. This means that even though we don’t know what the user likes yet, we still want our model to include things like “musical” because these movies might share some similarity with “Greatest showman”, despite not being explicitly mentioned in the user preference list.

Additionally, there is also a third parameter available called “user rating”. Each time someone rates something highly enough on imdb (e.g.: over four stars), then this gets added onto the overall score for future prediction models so far downstream where possible – but not before! If no such rating exists however? Well then maybe try looking elsewhere instead…

        inner join (select t.*, sum(avg(r.averageRating)*cnt)/sum((r.averageRating+0)*cnt) rate from ratings r join title_basics t using (tconst) group by t order by s.cst desc limit 1) d on s.tconst=d.tconst

```sql
SELECT
    * FROM (
        SELECT TOP 10 tconst AS TitleID,
                avg(rating) AS RatingScore
            FROM dbo.[Title Ratings]
            WHERE primaryTitle = @Movie AND numVotes > 5000 GROUP BY tconst ORDER BY RatingScore DESC
     ) AS RecommendationTable JOIN dbo.[Name Basics] ON RecommendationTable.primaryName=dbo.[Name Basics].primaryName  
     JOIN dbo.[Title Basics] ON RecommendationTable.tconst=dbo.[Title Basics].tconst
     JOIN dbo.[Title Crew] ON RecommendationTable.tconst=dbo.[Title Crew].tconst
     JOIN dbo.[Title Principals] ON RecommendationTable.tconst=dbo.[Title Principals].tconst
WHERE (
    ((RecommendationTable.category='actress') OR (RecommendationTable.job IN ('actor','artist'))))
AND (@Movie NOT LIKE '%Mars Attacks%' AND @Movie NOT LIKE '%Batman & Robin%')
GROUP BY RecommendationTable.TitleID
HAVING COUNT(*) >= 1
ORDER BY RatingScore DESC LIMIT 1 OFFSET @Offset
```

You have been asked to write an algorithm that takes the above User Input and User Preferences history and recommends them one movie from the Movie Database. Your algorithm must return the recommended movie along with its score. Your algorithm will also take into consideration any restrictions placed upon the user such as age group, gender, country and so forth.

Example
Given below are two sets of data representing the same set of inputs and outputs. It would look something similar to what you saw earlier but here we have added additional details. These details represent additional criteria that may affect how a movie gets selected as a recommendation.

Input | Output
---|---
My favourite genre is Horror. I want a good scare!! | 	Recommendation: Hostel  (2011), Score: 7
My favourite actor is Robert Englund. | Recommendation: Freddy vs Jason  (2003), Score: 8
My favourite actresses are Neve Campbell and Courteney Cox Arquette. | Recommendation: Scream  (1996), Score: 9

This time there were multiple factors taken into account when selecting a candidate for recommendation. This means you cannot simply select the highest scoring movie using just the average rating because that could potentially mean the worst rated movie overall might still get chosen due to other considerations. Therefore, you must create a method that returns both the best possible score AND the corresponding recommended movie. For example, even though the best scored movie according to average rating alone is The Shining  (1980), this movie does not match all requirements of our client and therefore cannot be recommended.

### Part Two:
Given an existing movie recommendation system, you must implement a new feature that allows the recommender system to rank the list of recommendations according to the distance between the preference vector of the user and the preference vectors of the recommendations themselves.

You may use any of the data provided above but make sure to store them in separate tables. Your final solution should consist of two main parts:
1. First part: A function that takes as inputs the movie recommendations and returns a ranked list of recommended movies ordered by decreasing similarity scores. For example, if the first item returned is very similar to the user's preferences then its score would be high while items further down the list would receive lower scores. This ranking algorithm must return a ranked list where the highest score corresponds to the best match possible.
2. Second part: Another function that accepts a pair consisting of the preference vector of a particular user and the preference vector of a particular recommended movie and returns true or false depending on whether they are sufficiently close together. If they are not sufficientlly close together, both functions must return false otherwise one or both of these functions might return different values for some pairs.

output:
```sql
SELECT * FROM title_basics WHERE titleType ='movie' AND titleType IS NOT NULL ORDER BY runtimeMinutes DESC LIMIT 1 OFFSET 1
UNION ALL SELECT * FROM title_ratings WHERE titleType IN ('movie') GROUP BY titleType HAVING COUNT(*) > 1 ORDER BY AVG(averageRating), COUNT(*) ASC LIMIT 1
UNION ALL SELECT * FROM title_principals JOIN actors ON title_principals.job LIKE '%actor%' OR title_principals.job LIKE '%actress%'' UNION ALL SELECT * FROM title_crew JOIN writers ON title_crew.writers LIKE '%writer%' OR title_crew.writers LIKE '%screenplay%'' UNION ALL SELECT * FROM title_principals JOIN crew ON title_principals.category= 'cast' AND title_principals.job LIKE '%character%' UNION ALL SELECT * FROM title_rating JOIN rating_users ON title_rating.numvotes>1 GROUP BY title_rating.title_id ORDER BY AVG(averageRating), count(*) asc limit 1
```

### Solution Explanation

The first part selects a random movie from the `title_basic` table where the `titleType` equals `'movie'` and `titleType` is not null. This means we select any movie that isn't an episode or video game and doesn't have an unspecified genre. We order these by duration so they aren't necessarily all short films since some may just have low durations because they were made quickly. The second part then selects every movie rated over one time. Since there could be multiple ratings per movie we want to make sure there are enough ratings before selecting them. Finally, we group those together into a single row by sorting alphabetically and using `limit`.

Then comes another union all. Firstly, we join the `title_principal` table onto itself twice once to find out who stars in what role and again to see who wrote what. Afterwards, we perform two additional joins to get the cast members and creators behind the scenes. Lastly, we use yet another union to gather all the details regarding how many times each movie was recommended to us and how many users voted on its rating.

            from title_ratings join title_basics ON title_ratings.tconst = title_basics.tconst where title_basics.primaryTitle = '$userInput')
           UNION ALL
         select title_basic.titleid, 
               avgrat AS ratedByAvg,
               null as totalReviewCount
           from title_ratings join title_basics ON title_ratings.tconst = title_basics.tconst WHERE title_basics.primaryTitle!= $userInput) t
      JOIN (((select distinct(category),job,avg(rating) OVER()) 
              from title_ratings join title_basics ON title_ratings.tconst = title_basics.tconst where title_basics.primaryTitle=$userInput group by category,job order by avg(rating)) t2 ) t3 on t3.category=t.category AND t3.job=t.job ORDER BY t3.avg DESC LIMIT 5

```sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS movieRecommendationResult AS (
    SELECT
        mr.*,
        1.0 * avg(rating) OVER () AS score,
        COUNT(*) OVER () AS count
    FROM
        (
            SELECT tconst,
                   SUM(CASE WHEN rtype = 'i' THEN rating ELSE NULL END) AS rating,
                   SUM(CASE WHEN rtype IN ('u','a') THEN rating ELSE NULL END) AS averageRating,
                   SUM((CASE WHEN rtype = 'i' OR rtype IS NULL THEN 1 ELSE 0 END)) AS numVotes
                FROM title_ratings tr JOIN rating r ON r.titleid=tr.tconst AND r.userid='' GROUP BY tconst ORDER BY avgrating DESC LIMIT 10
             UNION ALL
            SELECT tconst,
                   SUM(CASE WHEN rtype = 'i' THEN rating ELSE NULL END) AS rating,
                   SUM(CASE WHEN rtype IN ('u','a') THEN rating ELSE NULL END) AS averageRating,
                   SUM((CASE WHEN rtype = 'i' OR rtype IS NULL THEN 1 ELSE 0 END)) AS numVotes
              FROM title_ratings tr JOIN rating r ON r.titleid=tr.tconst AND r.userid<>'' GROUP BY tconst ORDER BY avgrating DESC LIMIT 10
        ) mr WHERE
       ((select count(*) from title_ratings where tconst = mr.tconst)>0);
```

output:
"""
The movie recommendation system generates suggestions based on two criteria: similarity between the previous rated movies and similarity between the previous rated actors.

To calculate the similarity score we use cosine distance measure between the vectors representing the ratings history.
We also take into account whether both actors appear together in any of the previously watched movies. This way the algorithm takes into account not just how similar the actor profiles are but also how likely they were seen acting together before.
Because we don't know exactly when an actor appeared in what role, there might still exist cases where one actor appears twice because he had different roles in two separate movies. To avoid those scenarios we check if the two actors appear in the same movie before returning the final list of candidates. If so then we remove them from our candidate pool.

In order to make sure that no duplicate entries get returned we store the last seen timestamp for every entry in our candidate set. Whenever we add a new entry we compare its time against already existing ones and return only those who haven't been recommended yet."""

SELECT * FROM
(
    SELECT t.*, 
        COUNT(*) AS viewCount, 
		COUNT(*)/AVG(CASE WHEN r.averageRating >= 7 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END)*100.0 AS score, 
		COUNT(*) OVER () AS totalRecommendationCount 
    FROM title_basic t INNER JOIN title_rating r ON t.primaryTitle = r.tconst AND r.numVotes > 0 GROUP BY t.titleType ORDER BY score DESC LIMIT 5  
    
) AS t WHERE t.viewCount BETWEEN 0 AND 1 OR t.totalRecommendationCount BETWEEN 0 AND 1 UNION ALL 
SELECT t.*, 
    CASE WHEN t.startYear < 1900 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END*100.0 AS score, 
	CASE WHEN t.startYear < 1900 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END + CASE WHEN t.startYear <= 1950 AND t.startYear >= 1900 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END+ CASE WHEN t.startYear <= 1970 AND t.startYear >= 1950 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END+ CASE WHEN t.startYear <= 1990 AND t.startYear >= 1970 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END+ CASE WHEN t.startYear <= 2000 AND t.startYear >= 1990 THEN 1 ELSE 0 END AS totalRecommendationCount, 
    COUNT(*) OVER () AS totalRecommendationCount 
FROM title_basic t INNER JOIN title_rating r ON t.primaryTitle = r.tconst AND r.numVotes > 0 GROUP BY t.titleType ORDER BY score DESC LIMIT 5  
    
) AS t WHERE t.score BETWEEN 0 AND 1 OR t.totalRecommendationCount BETWEEN 0 AND 1
```

### 11. Generic Data Warehouse

You are building a data warehouse to store information about products sold across multiple stores over time. Each product may be available in different stores but never simultaneously in two different stores. Some products will also become unavailable during some period of time. For example, the following data exists for Product 1:
* Available in Store X between Jan 2015 and Jun 2015
* Not currently available anywhere
* Was previously available in Store Z until Oct 2014

Create an EAV schema for storing these facts using the following attributes:
```sql
id (int not null constraint pk, auto increment)
store (varchar(2))
startDate (date)
endDate (date)
productCode (varchar(10), constraint uq, index)
```

The first attribute `id` would serve as the primary key, however, you don't want any values repeated so you add a UNIQUE CONSTRAINT to ensure no duplicates exist. The second attribute `store` allows us to specify whether the fact applies to a particular store, while the third and fourth allow us to track when we were able to purchase the item, and what code the item had at that moment. We use `constraint uq`, because we know there could potentially be duplicate codes, but they shouldn't overlap.

Write a SELECT statement that returns one row per day for every month between May 2014 and July 2015 inclusive, and group them together into months. This means the final result set should look like something similar to the image below.
![](https://i.imgur.com/GJbvQOE.png)
Note that you do NOT need to create indexes here. Instead, show how you would write the queries needed to perform this functionality.

**Hint #1:** Use an INNER JOIN instead of LEFT OUTER JOINS to avoid returning NULL values. If possible, try to eliminate subqueries altogether.

### Part Two
Now you have learned how to write SQL queries using various data sources such as MySQL, PostgresQL, Redis DB, JSON files, CSV files, Excel sheets, XML files, etc. But now let us try something different. This time we will use an API endpoint provided by one of our partner sites. For example, Amazon’s API allows access to its product catalogue so you could get book recommendations via its search APIs. Another interesting thing here is that some products might not exist anymore but they still appear in the catalog because those products were once sold there before being discontinued. So when building your application make sure you handle these kinds of situations gracefully since no matter what happens everything needs to work properly even though sometimes things go wrong unexpectedly due to unforeseen circumstances beyond anyone control including yours!

So far every time someone asked me “What kinda stuff did u learn?” My response always started off with either Java OR C++ BUT THIS TIME IT WILL BE DIFFERENT!!! Now instead saying JAVA OR C++, I am going tell them exactly WHAT I LEARNED!! Because I learned SO MUCH STUFF while working through this project!!

### Part Three
In part two we saw how easy it really isn't just writing code inside IDEs (Integrated Development Environments). Instead developers usually spend hours upon weeks designing mockups before ever getting down into actual implementation details themselves thus resulting in poor quality solutions created under pressure leaving little room left over afterwards meaning less time spent debugging later which leads directly back towards design problems again...so why bother trying anything new?
